an5.7:4.1: “Mendicants, sentient beings are mostly charmed by sensual pleasures.
an5.7:4.2: When someone from a respectable family has left behind the scythe and flail and gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a faithful renunciant from a respectable family’.
an5.7:4.4: Because a youth can get sensual pleasures of this kind or that.
an5.7:4.5: Now, all sensual pleasures are just considered as ‘sensual pleasures’, regardless of whether they’re inferior, average, or superior.
an5.7:4.6: Suppose there was a little baby boy who, because of his nurse’s negligence, puts a stick or stone in his mouth.
an5.7:4.7: The nurse would very quickly notice
an5.7:4.8: and try to take it out.
an5.7:4.9: If that didn’t work, she’d cradle his head with her left hand, and take it out using a hooked finger of her right hand, even if it drew blood.
an5.7:4.11: I admit she’d know, ‘This will distress the child,
an5.7:4.13: Still, it should be done by a nurse who wants what’s best for him, out of kindness and compassion.
an5.7:4.14: And when the boy has grown up and has enough sense, his nurse would not worry about him, thinking:
an5.7:4.15: ‘The boy can look after himself. He won’t be negligent.’
an5.7:5.1: In the same way, I still need to look after a mendicant who hasn’t finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding wholesome qualities.
an5.7:5.2: But when a mendicant has finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding wholesome qualities, I think:
an5.7:5.3: ‘They can look after themselves. They won’t be negligent.’
